definition: a bowed stringed instrument with a thin wooden soundboard
to catch sight of in a doorway (old)
see 老闆|老板, boss
board/plank/plate/shutter/table tennis bat/clappers (music)/CL:塊|块[kuai4]/accented beat in Chinese music/hard/stiff/to stop smiling or look serious
surname Hu
non-Han people, esp. from central Asia/reckless/outrageous/what?/why?/to complete a winning hand at mahjong (also written 和[hu2])
beard/mustache/whiskers
see 衚衕|胡同[hu2 tong4]
jinghu, a smaller, higher-pitched erhu 二胡 (two-stringed fiddle) used to accompany Chinese opera/also called 京二胡
erhu (Chinese 2-string fiddle)/alto fiddle/CL:把[ba3]
sihu (or "khuurchir" in Mongolian), a bowed instrument with four strings, primarily associated with Mongolian and Chinese culture
same as 墜胡|坠胡[zhui4 hu2]
yangqin/dulcimer (hammered string musical instrument)
huqin/family of Chinese two-stringed fiddles, with snakeskin covered wooden soundbox and bamboo bow with horsehair bowstring
two-stringed bowed instrument/also called 墜琴|坠琴[zhui4 qin2]
small drum for marking time
suona, Chinese shawm (oboe), used in festivals and processions or for military purposes/also written 鎖吶|锁呐/also called 喇叭[la3 ba5]
sanxian, large family of 3-stringed plucked musical instruments, with snakeskin covered wooden soundbox and long neck, used in folk music, opera and Chinese orchestra
plucked string music
jing'erhu, a two-stringed fiddle intermediate in size and pitch between the jinghu 京胡 and erhu 二胡, used to accompany Chinese opera/also called 京胡
clapper-board
liuqin lute, smaller version of the pipa 琵琶, with holes in the soundbox, and range similar to that of a violin
zhongruan or alto lute, like pipa 琵琶 but bigger and lower range
double bass/contrabass
